author: domenico
post: According to the Nature’s article: “All laboratories examined the textile samples microscopically to identify and REMOVE any foreign material….. AFTER these initial cleaning procedures, each laboratory split the samples for further treatment. The Arizona group split each sample into four subsamples…”. Jull in his recent paper states that he found cotton fibers in his sample. But that’s impossible if Nature tell us the truth! from Nature’s: “The Arizona group split each sample into four subsamples. One pair of subsamples from each textile was treated with dilute HCL, dilute Na OH and again in acid, with rinsing in between (method a). The second pair of subsamples was treated with a commercial detergent (1.5% SDS), distilled water, 0.1% HCL and another detergent (1.5% triton X 100)…”. Again: How could prof. Jull have found in his sample wax, spores, iron oxide if the 4 subsamples were treated?.

post: Ann Hedlund, the textile expert consulted by Jull, established that the warp fabric count is 30 yarns per cm (76 per inch) and the weft is 40 yarns per cm (102 inch). That is very strange since other experts counted differently: Timossi: warp/40 weft/27 Raes: warp/38,6 weft/25,7 Vial: Warp/37,6 weft/25,8 Vercelli: warp/36 weft/24 Hedlund/Jull: warp/30 weft/40.

author: domenico
post: Raes examined the so called “Raes Corner”; as the name suggests it’s a piece of textile even more external that this of the carbon dating; So when Raes writes “main cloth” he means the border, an area that could have easily been manipulated. Only in this area we have a verified presence of cotton inside the linen threads. Http://www.ohioshroudconference.com/a17.htm Rogers writes: “Cotton fibers are easy to find mixed intimately with the linen fibers of Part I Raes threads….I do not attempt to make a quantitative cotton comparison between Raes and radiocarbon threads and Shroud tapes, because there was too little cotton of any kind on Shroud samples. We had been puzzled by the Raes report at the time of the 1978 STURP observations in Turin. We could not find more than traces of cotton on the Shroud. The cloth appeared to be pure linen.” (Rogers, “A Chemist’s Perspective On The Shroud of Turin”, p.66).
title: The Question of Cotton in the Shroud of Turin’s Yarn
